title: How is Cuba politically stable? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well… What a complex question to answer… As a Cuban citizen, older than 18 years old (and therefore adult according to the Cuban laws, I’m 19), living all my life in Cuba (never been in other countries before mostly because my family has no money to travel for leisure), spending (or should I say wasting) my time serving the army in the Obligatory Military Service and as a member of the UJC (Communist Young Union, heritage of the AJR, Association of Young Rebels, founded by Major. Ernesto Guevara “El Che”) I feel able to talk with confidence about the Cuban pollitical stabillity. Well, in the first place, I may begin telling that there’s (STILL) a strong union between the people and its leaders. Since Osvaldo Dorticós Torrado, who was president until 1973 (while Fidel was Prime Minister), we have had 3 presidents: * Cmdr. in Chief Fidel Castro Ruz, * General of the Army, Raul Castro Ruz * Miguel Mario Díaz-Canel Bermúdez. Fidel… You may criticize Fidel, you may state he’s a dictator, you may state several things about Fidel’s person. Some may be true (we can’t be blind). He commited mistakes, true. He unmounted once the sugar factories when the sugar price got low, and some other stuff he did. Yeah, ok. That’s true. But the facts says that even with those mistakes, Cuban people always supported Fidel. And that’s completely true. I can even tell you, once in august, 1994 (the worse years of the Special Period in time of peace, the period following the U.S.S.R collapse) the people got rebel in La Habana. There was a huge manifestation. People yelling “Abajo la Revolución!” and so. Stone throwing started. Then Fidel came into scene. He dismounted the vehicle he was in. He approached to the populace, he grabbed a stone and he said that he also wanted to throw stones too. Everybody inmediately (EVERYBODY) changed their minds and starting praising him. It’s madness but it’s completely true. I don’t know if that fact is studied anywhere outside from Cuba. Why did they praised him, even when people had to eat cats and dogs, some had to travel over 40 miles in bycicle to get the food to feed their families? Well, I disagree to the “common” opinion that Cuba was a paradise before 1959. My mother’s family was landowner and they did not had any economic issues (they even got a TV, one of the first in the Cuban eastern, historically the poorest region) but my father’s… My father’s family was another thing. My granma was farmer that never went to the school. She has 6th degree I think. My granma gave birth to six children on a hill, three of them before 1959. It was hard for them to survive, since my grandfather left my grandmother alone. That was the situation of the Cuban farmers before 1959. They starved to death, while the woman gave birth 5, 10, 20 kids. The kids then grew up with no healthcare available… I may continue, but I’m going to stop here to state this: Being Fidel the soul (yes, the soul, no chovinism involved) of the Cuban Revolution, then Fidel provided us: * An alphabetization campaign that taught to read and write to the 97% of the Cubans. * Free healthcare (to everyone), in a time when free healthcare was a privilege of developed countries. * An important development (contrary to what “everybody” says) on industry. (Watch the full interview of El Ché and Lisa Howard) * The practice of sports as a right of the people. That’s why all the cuban sportsman are amateur. * A hope that things would improve. And they actually did, until the collapse of the Soviet Union. Then everything went down the sink, yet the Cuban people did not lost their will to fight, and to survive, and to develop. We never rennounced to free universal healthcare, to free education, to free (and supported by the state) practice of sports… And all of that was thanks to Fidel labour. So, he commited mistakes, he was human. Yes, he was an authoritarian person, that was a part of his personality. He never liked losing anything and he liked being in control. Another mistake commited (not by him this time) was that no one ever dared to diverge from his opinions, nor in private or in public. Yet, I feel lucky, because thanks to Fidel’s labour (and Raul’s labour by extension) my father, son of a farmer, was able to graduate on Informatics and came to be Vicepresident of a Conglomerate (state conglomerate, of course). Well, Miguel Díaz-Canel represents continuity from the ideas of Fidel. He started having rather low approval but after we saw what was he doing we started liking him better. During the tornado that stroke Havana in January 28 2018 (Jose Martí’s birthday) he went personally to visit the people that were left with nothing at all. He occupied of those people. Since Díaz-Canel rise to the power, we have seen incremented the communication between the people and the government institutions. And almost everybody approves the government management of COVID-19. Well. That was the positive thing. Now for the negative, as a true revolutionary shall always know the flaws of the social project we build, in order to be able to repair those flaws. Repression in Cuba is an undisputable fact. It exists indeed. I have never been repressed or censored anyway (although I’m not a political activist) for listening american music, for example. I’m a heavy metal fan, a genre which perhaps it’s incompatible to the cuban culture (as some people may want to make believe), but I have never been repressed for listening that “imperialist music” anyway. Well, for some, repression is a fact. Everybody has repression, don’t be blind anyway and don’t judge by external influences. Many massive media journalist speaking shit about Cuba have never been actually in Cuba, and those who has been come to Cuba to enjoy the beaches and “Raul Castro’s hotels” (omg) and they like them, so, please, those people, stop with the hipocrisy. Cuba has a very efficient intelligence service inside of the Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces (to which I belong now since I’m serving for a year, so I can give first hand information about it. I serve at those Intelligence Services) And Cuban government has the WHOLE army of their side. The WHOLE i said. I mean, many high PCC (Communist Party) chairmans are members of the FAR (the armed forces). By the way, Raul Castro does not belongs to the FAR since 2008. He was FAR’s minister since 1959 to 2008, but now he’s not member of the FAR. As every retired Cuban military staff member, he still preserves the military rank. Those intelligence services are used to neutralize any threat to the Cuban national security (speaking in U.S terms; just as U.S does anyway) Threats are for example, journalists that are payed to speak bad things about Cuba and so. Things like Cuban medic personnel are slaves… omg. I have an aunt that’s doctor. Well is currently on Angola. She told me once that she feels in debt to the Cuban Revolution, for letting her study and become a doctor. Without Cuban Revolution she would probably have becomed farmer, just as my granma was. By the way, I have never been starving. I’m hungry now, but nothing that can’t be solved with a travel to the fridge. ¡Patria o Muerte!¡Venceremos! POSTDATA: Really, need to watch the interview of El Ché with Lisa Howard. It’s freaking awesome.

Cuba is stable by its oppressive authoritarian regime, It has good healthcare but it doesn’t compare to the freedom seen in the USA or EU as you aren’t allowed to criticize the government or Raul Castro, and of you do you will be imprisoned and even possibly tortured and killed. Just read this article by human rights watch, World Report 2020: Rights Trends in Cuba
Absolute repression. Dissent is punished and only one party permitted. Your ration card will be pulled if you get out of hand.
